text.p: Denmark's third-largest insurer, Topdanmark, on Tuesday reported 1996 profits up to 272 million crowns from 26 million the year before and forecast a result of 330-380 million crowns after tax in 1997.

It more than doubled its operating result to 273 million crowns from 1995's 130 million and logged a 9.8 percent return on own capital but a Topdanmark statement said that the results still left something to be desired.

"The result can still not be described as completely satisfactory. This is because Topdanmark has increased provisions, with the consequence that the accident insurance business has not attained a satisfactory level," it said.
The accident operation logged a 229 million crown profit in 1996, up from 172 million the year before. Life insurance profit was up to 36 million crowns, from 32 million.
Topdanmark added that its combined ratio, at 104.5 in 1996, was still far off the targeted 100.

But it said that measures introduced in 1996 and the beginning of 1997 would swell the coming year's profits, among them the closure of its Topdanmark Bank unit as part of a strategy of concentrating on core insurance business.
It sold its guarantee insurance unit to BG Bank for 25 million crowns on January 1, it said, and expected to make another 30 million from the sale of its 17 percent holding in Sydbank.
"These events will all effect earnings in 1997 in a positive way," the statement said.
